node.title: Meat Is Hard for Hungry Families to Come By. Enter These Deer Hunters.
node.alt: Mike Aversa, who has been hunting since he was 10, helped start a charity that donates excess deer meat to food banks and soup kitchens.
node.description: Hunters in New Jersey have shared 2.2 million pounds of deer meat since 1997. “This provides a source of protein that we wouldn’t otherwise have,” a food bank manager says.
node.content: ["", "Mike Aversa, a semiretired accountant, goes hunting as often as possible.", "He uses the first six or seven deer he shoots each season to stock his family\u2019s freezer and table. Venison chili, venison meatballs and venison sausage are staples in his house in Annandale, a community in western New Jersey.", "In 1997, a desire to do what he could to share the much-needed source of protein with food-insecure families \u2014 while indulging a hobby and addressing the state\u2019s severe overpopulation of deer \u2014 motivated Mr. Aversa to join with two friends and found Hunters Helping the Hungry.", "A quarter century later, the program is considered one of the top three game-meat donation programs in the country, according to a study by a firearms trade association. Since its start, the all-volunteer nonprofit has arranged for the donation of 14,731 deer \u2014 about 2.2 million quarter-pound servings of fresh, lean protein \u2014 to New Jersey residents in need.", "Two recent coronavirus pandemic grants from the U.S. Department of Agriculture, through the New Jersey Farm Bureau, enabled the program to expand and to waive the $20 cost of donating a deer for participating hunters.", "\u201cThe idea is, \u2018Take what you need for yourself. But don\u2019t stop,\u2019 \u201d said Mr. Aversa, a former partner at a large accounting firm in New Jersey. He has been hunting since he was 10.", "The concept is as simple as it is effective: Hunters bring their excess harvest to one of seven participating butcher shops, where the deer are dressed and frozen into roasts, steaks, tenderloins and ground meat.", "The venison then goes to regional food banks to be distributed to soup kitchens and food pantries, where meats and sources of protein are often in short supply and where demand surged during the early phase of the pandemic.", "\u201cThe agencies \u2014 they start asking at the beginning of September: \u2018Do you have venison yet?\u2019\u201d said Shannon Williams, assistant director of a food bank in northwestern New Jersey, Norwescap.", "\u201cMeat is very hard to come by,\u201d she added. \u201cThis provides a source of protein that we wouldn\u2019t otherwise have.\u201d", "The overpopulation of deer in New Jersey is a well-known hazard that contributes to crop damage and car accidents, particularly during mating season.", "In 2019, between October and December, there were 4,753 collisions between cars and animals, primarily deer, in New Jersey, according to an analysis by AAA Northeast, the most recent data of such collisions available.", "In New York, where deers have also proliferated, the number of animal crashes in 2020 \u2014 33,956 \u2014 included six fatalities, the travel group found. Suffolk County, where a deer was filmed in 2019 bursting through the glass front door of a beauty salon on a main street in Lake Ronkonkoma, had the state\u2019s second-highest number of animal collisions, 1,311, trailing Orange County by just 116.", "To address the problem in New Jersey, the state has expanded hunting onto county parkland at specified times of year and offered special licenses to farmers to shoot deer on their property during regulated depredation hunts.", "Two years of federal grants have enabled the New Jersey hunters\u2019 program to purchase a refrigerated truck that, upon request, is transported to farmland to collect deer shot during the hunts \u2014 meat that in prior years had mainly gone to waste.", "Until last year, the program relied primarily on monetary donations to cover the roughly $90 cost of butchering each deer, and required hunters to make a tax-deductible contribution to offset the butchering expense. The grants have enabled the hunger program to waive that fee as well.", "\u201cThere were years when we actually had so many deers donated that we ran out of money,\u201d said Bud Thomas, the group\u2019s longtime treasurer.", "Similar game-meat donation programs operate in other parts of the country, with Virginia, Iowa and Missouri providing some of the highest volumes of donated venison. Unlike groups in other states, New Jersey\u2019s program accepts only deer, and each participating butcher must operate from facilities that pass state health inspections.", "\u201cI\u2019ve been offered geese, bear, caribou,\u201d said Mr. Thomas, referring mainly to game shot outside of New Jersey. \u201cI think I was offered a moose at one point.\u201d", "Bob Wilson, an avid hunter, fisherman and marathon runner, helped found the Cranford Rod and Gun Club in 1968.", "He enjoys bowhunting. But he does not have a taste for venison.", "\u201cI\u2019m not a big fan of it,\u201d said Mr. Wilson, 74. \u201cI just love hunting, being outside in the woods.\u201d", "Every year, his first three or four deer go to family and friends. After that, anything he shoots goes to the hunger program.", "He said he typically donated about two deer during the roughly six-month bow season that runs from September into February. This year, he is waiting for his first catch.", "\u201cIt\u2019s a long season. I know my luck\u2019s going to change,\u201d he said. \u201cIf I\u2019m not hunting, I\u2019m fishing. It\u2019s never a wasted day.\u201d", "Seeing dead deer on the roadside frustrates him, forcing him to think about the unused meat and the suffering the animal and the driver likely endured.", "\u201cInstead of going to waste, it\u2019s going to food banks,\u201d Mr. Wilson said of the reason he makes the effort to transport deer about 45 minutes from where he lives to a participating butcher in Whitehouse Station, N.J., V. Roche and Sons. \u201cIt\u2019s healthy, healthy food.\u201d", "The main hurdle keeping the program from expanding is the need for additional butchers willing to help coordinate with food banks and who can manage the state health inspections, according to board members of Hunters Helping the Hungry.", "John (J.B.) Person runs a family-owned butcher shop, Game Butchers, in Lebanon, N.J., and participates in the feeding program.", "He likened venison to grass-fed beef.", "\u201cIt\u2019s very lean. It\u2019s not fatty,\u201d he said. \u201cBut you can only eat so much, can only take home so much.\u201d", "After butchering the donated deer, he flash freezes it and stores it until it can be picked up by food banks.", "\u201cLet me tell you: It\u2019s a wanted and very much needed protein,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s gone in days.\u201d"]
